questions.text: Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Tyrosine is the amino acid forming Serotonin
Niacin deficiency is seen in Carcinoid syndrome
Tryptophan hydroxylase is required for Niacin synthesis
Decarboxylation of 5 hydroxy tryptophan forms niacin.

questions.solution:
• Tryptophan forms both niacin and serotonin. (Option A)
  • Carcinoid syndrome causes excess production of serotonin by carcinoid tumors and tryptophan is deficient for the synthesis of niacin causing niacin deficiency.

Synthesis of Serotonin

 

Other causes of niacin deficiency include Hartnup's disease, in maize eaters, and drugs like Isoniazid

Tryptophan hydroxylase is required for Niacin synthesis (Option C): Tryptophan hydroxylase is required for the synthesis of serotonin

Decarboxylation of 5 hydroxy tryptophan forms niacin (Option D): Decarboxylation of 5 hydroxy tryptophan forms serotonin

questions.text:
Match the following urinary odours with their corresponding diagnoses:


	
		
			
			Urinary Odour
			
			
			Diagnosis
			
		
		
			
			1. Mousy odour
			
			
			a. DKA (Diabetic Ketoacidosis)
			
		
		
			
			2. Fruity odour
			
			
			b. Hawkinsinuria
			
		
		
			
			3. Cabbage odour
			
			
			c. Methionine malabsorption
			
		
		
			
			4. Swimming pool odour
			
			
			d. PKU (Phenylketonuria)
			
		
		
			
			5. Oast house odour
			
			
			e. Type 1 Tyrosinemia

A 45-year-old patient presents with episodes of palpitations, sweating, and severe headaches. These episodes occur intermittently and are associated with hypertension. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of plasma free metanephrines and urinary Vanillyl Mandelic Acid. Which of the following enzymes are directly involved in the synthesis of these metabolites?
questions.solution:
• Monoamine oxidase & Catechol-O-methyltransferase are directly involved in the metabolism of catecholamines, leading to the formation of metanephrines and vanillylmandelic acid (VMA).

 

  • In Pheochromocytoma, there is elevation of catecholamines leading to increased breakdown of epinephrine and norepinephrine, consequently increased levels of metabolites such as metanephrines and vanillylmandelic acid.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Segawa syndrome is incorrect?

choices.text: Patients have a defect in the GTP cyclohydrolase enzyme.
Females are more commonly affected than males.

questions.solution:
In Segawa syndrome, blood phenylalanine levels are high. The syndrome is characterized by a defect in the GTP cyclohydrolase enzyme, which leads to reduced levels of tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4).

Segawa Syndrome / Dopa-responsive dystonia (DRD)

Inheritance Pattern

Autosomal dominant (Option A)

Clinical Features

Dystonia with diurnal variation (worsens in the afternoon and evening)

Incidence based on sex

More common in females than males (Option D)

Genetic Mutation

Defect in the GTP cyclohydrolase enzyme (Option B)

Biochemical Findings
  • Reduced tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) levels
  • Normal or high blood phenylalanine levels
  • CSF Biopterin levels are low

Diagnosis
  • Clinical observation of dystonia patterns
  • Genetic testing for GTP cyclohydrolase enzyme mutation

questions.text: A newborn screening test reveals elevated phenylalanine levels, prompting further investigation. Genetic testing indicates a defect in dihydrobiopterin reductase. Based on this information, Which type of phenylketonuria does the patient most likely have?
questions.solution:
Non-classic phenylketonuria Type II is characterized by a defect in dihydrobiopterin reductase.

Type

Enzyme Defect

Description

Classic PKU (Option A)

Phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH)

Defect in PAH leads to elevated phenylalanine levels and symptoms such as developmental delays and musty odor.

Non-classical PKU Type II & III

Dihydrobiopterin reductase

Defect in dihydrobiopterin reductase, leading to elevated phenylalanine levels.

Non-classical PKU Type IV & V (Option C & D)

Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) formation

Defect in the formation of tetrahydrobiopterin, a cofactor needed for phenylalanine hydroxylase, leading to hyperphenylalaninemia.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the ophthalmologist by his parents due to progressive vision loss, particularly at night. Fundoscopic examination reveals circular areas of chorioretinal atrophy and peripheral retinal degeneration. Laboratory tests indicate markedly elevated plasma ornithine levels. What is the primary biochemical defect in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
• Gyrate atrophy of the retina is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme ornithine aminotransferase (OAT), which leads to the accumulation of ornithine in the plasma.
  • Ornithine is toxic to the retinal pigment epithelium and causes gyrate atrophy of the retina.
  • This condition manifests with progressive vision loss, especially night blindness, and characteristic fundoscopic findings of chorioretinal atrophy.
  • Management includes a Arginine restricted diet and vitamin B6 supplementation, as OAT activity can be B6-dependent in some patients.

Ornithine transcarbamylase (Option A) is involved in the urea cycle, not directly related to gyrate atrophy.

Ornithine decarboxylase (Option C) is involved in polyamine synthesis, not related to ornithine accumulation or retinal degeneration.

Ornithine cyclodeaminase (Option D) is not related to the metabolic pathway implicated in gyrate atrophy.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to recurrent kidney stones and abdominal pain. Urinalysis reveals hexagonal crystals, and a 24-hour urine test shows elevated levels of cystine. Which condition is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
•  

Cystinuria (Option A) is correct because it is caused by the defect of a transporter that reabsorbs cysteine, ornithine , lysine and arginine in PCT and it causes recurrent kidney stones and hexagonal cystine crystals

Cystinosis (Option B) is incorrect is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a defect in the transport protein cystinosin, leading to cystine accumulation within cells and formation of crystals in various tissues, including the cornea, causing photophobia.

  • This condition also results in kidney damage, causing symptoms like polyuria and polydipsia, and recurrent kidney stones.
  • The presence of characteristic crystals in the cornea on slit-lamp examination and hexagonal crystals in the urine supports the diagnosis of cystinosis.

Hyperoxaluria (Option C) is incorrect because it leads to calcium oxalate stones (not cystine stones) and does not cause corneal deposits or Fanconi syndrome.

Nephrocalcinosis (Option D) is incorrect because it refers to calcium deposition in the kidney and does not explain cystine crystals, Fanconi syndrome, or corneal involvement.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is evaluated for developmental delay. Physical examination reveals a tall, thin build, scoliosis, and ectopia lentis. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of homocysteine and methionine in the plasma. Treatment is initiated with vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) and folate. Homocysteine levels improve, but methionine levels remain elevated. Based on this scenario, what type of defect does the patient most likely have?
questions.solution:
Type 1 vs Type 2 Homocystinuria:

Feature

Type - I Homocystinuria

Type - II Homocystinuria

Enzyme Deficiency

Cystathionine beta-synthase

Methionine synthase

Metabolic Pathway Affected

Homocysteine to cystathionine

Homocysteine to methionine

Elevated Metabolites

Homocysteine and methionine

Homocysteine and elevated levels of methionine

Biochemical Diagnosis
  • Low levels of cysteine.
  • High levels of methionine.
  • High levels of cysteine.
  • Low levels of methionine.

Treatment
  • Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) supplementation; low-methionine diet; cysteine supplementation

Vitamin B12 and folate supplementation; low-methionine diet


 

Type 3 Homocystinuria (Option C) is a rare form not commonly linked with elevated methionine and does not match the patient's response to treatment.

Marfan Syndrome (Option D) shares some physical traits (tall stature, scoliosis) but it does not include elevated homocysteine levels or vitamin B6 response.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought with recurrent episodes of a red, scaly rash that worsens with sun exposure, as well as intermittent episodes of diarrhea and mood changes. A urine sample reveals an abnormal presence of neutral amino acids. The patient's diet is balanced, and there is no history of similar symptoms in the family. Laboratory tests indicate a deficiency in niacin despite adequate dietary intake. What is the underlying cause of the patient's condition?

choices.text: Deficiency in the neutral amino acid transporter

questions.solution:
Hartnup’s disease:

  • It is caused by a defect in the neutral amino acid transporter in the kidneys and intestines, leading to poor absorption and increased excretion of neutral amino acids like tryptophan.
  • This results in decreased availability of tryptophan for niacin synthesis, leading to symptoms similar to pellagra despite adequate dietary intake.
  • The characteristic skin rash, diarrhea, and mood changes are consistent with this diagnosis.

Tryptophan hydroxylase (Option A) is involved in serotonin synthesis, not amino acid transport.

Overactivity of serotonin decarboxylase (Option C) would affect serotonin levels, not amino acid transport.

Excessive dietary leucine (Option D) can interfere with tryptophan metabolism, but it is not the primary cause of Hartnup's disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with symptoms of diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. On further investigation, his diet is found to be predominantly corn-based, and he has a history of alcohol use disorder. Laboratory tests reveal low levels of tryptophan and niacin in his blood. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely contributing to the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
• Pellagra is a condition that results from a deficiency of niacin (vitamin B3) or tryptophan.
  • It is characterized by three main symptoms: dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia.
  • Kynureninase is an enzyme in the kynurenine pathway, responsible for converting tryptophan to niacin.
  • A low activity of this enzyme is observed in B6 deficiency, which is caused by alcoholism. This can exacerbate pellagra caused by maize or corn intake.

 

Causes of Pellagra:

  • Diet with
    • Niacin deficiency.
    • Tryptophan (60 mg Tryptophan = 1 mg Niacin) deficiency in the maize-based diet.
    • Tryptophan malabsorption - Hartnup's disease.
  • Carcinoid Syndrome - Tryptophan is used to form Serotonin leading to niacin deficiency
  • Vitamin B6 deficiency - inactivates Kynenurinase.
  • Leucine pellagra - Quinolinate phosphoribosyltransferase (QPRTASE) enzyme is inhibited in a leucine-rich diet. Example: sorghum diet which is rich in leucine.

 

Tryptophan hydroxylase (Option A) converts tryptophan to 5-hydroxytryptophan in the serotonin synthesis pathway, not involved in niacin synthesis.

Serotonin decarboxylase (Option C) converts 5-hydroxytryptophan to serotonin, not in niacin synthesis.

Niacinamide adenine dinucleotide synthetase (Option D) converts niacinamide to NAD (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide), a form of niacin. It is not directly related to the metabolism of tryptophan into niacin.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the metabolism of phenylalanine is incorrect?

choices.text: Phenylalanine is converted to tyrosine catalyzed by phenylalanine hydroxylase.
Phenylalanine on transamination gets converted to phenylpyruvate
Phenylpyruvate on oxidation yields phenyl lactate
Phenylpyruvate on oxidative decarboxylation forms phenylacetate.

questions.solution:
Phenylpyruvate on reduction, not oxidation, yields phenyl lactate. 

Phenylalanine has 2 metabolic fates in the body:

Major Fate
  • Phenylalanine is converted into tyrosine by the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase.
  • Deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase results in Phenylketonuria.
  • It requires tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) as a cofactor

Minor Fate

Phenylalanine is converted into phenylpyruvate by transamination.

Phenylpyruvate can further undergo different pathways:

  • Phenylpyruvate can be reduced to phenyl lactate
  • Phenylpyruvate undergoes oxidative decarboxylation, forming phenylacetate
  • Phenylacetate combines with glutamine to form phenylacetylglutamine, which is excreted in the urine.

questions.text: Which of the following TCA intermediates is not formed by glucogenic amino acids?
questions.solution:
Glucogenic amino acids give rise to 4 intermediates of TCA

  • Alpha Ketoglutarate
  • Succinyl CoA
  • Fumarate
  • Oxaloacetate

Amino acids give rise to:

  • Alpha-ketoglutarate (on Transamination)
    • Glutamate
    • Glutamine
    • Histidine
    • Proline
    • Arginine
  • Succinyl CoA
    • V- Valine
    • I- Isoleucine
    • M- Methionine
    • (Mnemonic- VIM)
  • Fumarate
    • Phenylalanine
    • Tyrosine
  • Oxaloacetate (on Transamination)
    • Aspartate
    • Asparagine

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids are both glucogenic and ketogenic?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Tryptophan

 

Explanation:

  • Tryptophan is both glucogenic and ketogenic.
  • Tryptophan on catabolism gives one of the glycolytic intermediate - Pyruvate or TCA cycle intermediate other than Acetyl CoA.

 

Classification of Amino Acid Catabolism





 

Purely Ketogenic

Purely Glucogenic

Both Ketogenic and Glucogenic

On catabolism gives only acetyl CoA

On catabolism gives only pyruvate

Substance on catabolism gives one of the glycolytic intermediate -Pyruvate or TCA cycle intermediate

other than Acetyl CoA

Amino acids are:

  • Leucine
  • Lysine

Amino acids are:

  • Alanine: On transamination yields pyruvate.
  • Glycine: Simplest amino acid.
  • 3-hydroxyl group- containing amino acids
    • Serine
    • Threonine
    • Hydroxyproline
  • Sulphur-containing amino acid
    • Cysteine

Amino acids are:

  • Aromatic amino acids
    • Phenylalanine
    • Tyrosine
    • Tryptophan
  • Branched-chain amino acid
    • Isoleucine
    • Threonine

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant has been having developmental delays. Further examination reveals a defect in the enzyme called phenylalanine hydroxylase. Which of the following urine odor is seen in this infant?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is a case of phenylketonuria which causes 3 main clinical features:

  • Mental retardation
  • Hypopigmentation
  • Mousy odour

Phenylketonuria (PKU):

  • Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an autosomal recessive inborn error of metabolism caused by a deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase or its cofactor tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4).
  • This deficiency leads to an accumulation of phenylalanine and its metabolites, including phenylpyruvic acid.

Mental Retardation:

  • Cause: Mental retardation in phenylketonuria (PKU) is due to the accumulation of phenylketones, which compete with other neutral amino acids for transport across the blood-brain barrier.
  • Management: To prevent mental retardation, a phenylalanine-restricted diet should be followed, along with tyrosine supplements.

Hypopigmentation:

  • Cause: Reduced melanin production in PKU results from a deficiency in tyrosine, a crucial component for melanin synthesis. This leads to lighter skin and hair color compared to individuals without PKU.

Musty/ Mousy urine odor:

  • Cause: Due to the accumulation of phenylpyruvic acid (a metabolite of excess phenylalanine) in the urine.

 

ODOUR

DISORDERS

Musty/ Mousy odour

PKU

Fruity odour

DKA (diabetic ketoacidosis)

Cabbage odour

Type 1 Tyrosinemia

Burnt sugar

Maple syrup urine disease

Oast house or beer baby syndrome

Hypermethioninemia

Swimming pool odour

Hawkinsinuria

Tom-cat urine odour

Multiple carboxylase deficiency

Sweaty feet odour

Isovaleric acidemia

Fish odour

Trimethylaminuria

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with a lack of pigmentation in their skin, hair, and eyes. The parents are concerned about the child's sensitivity to sunlight and the involuntary back-and-forth eye movements that the child exhibits. A significant decrease in melanin pigmentation is present. Which of the following enzymes is absent or deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
• Melanin is a pigment produced by cells called melanocytes, and it plays a critical role in determining the colour of our skin, hair, and eyes.
  • Tyrosinase catalyzes the first two steps in the conversion of the amino acid tyrosine to melanin.

 

Tyrosine → L-Dopa → Dopaquinone

 

  • Without enough functional tyrosinase, melanin production is reduced or completely absent, leading to the characteristic features of albinism.

 

Reaction

Enzyme

Tyrosine to DOPA

Tyrosine hydroxylase/ Tyrosinase

DOPA to Melanin

Non-enzyme catalyzed chemical reaction

Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) (Option A) is a liver enzyme that is released into the bloodstream when the liver is damaged.

Phenylalanine hydroxylase (Option C) is an enzyme that converts phenylalanine to tyrosine. A deficiency in this enzyme leads to phenylketonuria (PKU).

S-adenosylmethionine (Option D) required for:

  • Norepinephrine to Epinephrine:
    • Enzyme: Phenylethanolamine N-methyltransferase (PNMT).
  • Conversion of Homocysteine to Methionine:
    • Enzyme: Methionine synthase, using methylcobalamin as a cofactor.
  • Methylation of DNA:
    • SAM donates methyl groups to cytosine residues, affecting gene expression.
  • Synthesis of Creatine:
    • SAM is involved in the methylation of guanidinoacetate to form creatine.
  • Methylation of Neurotransmitters:
    • SAM is also involved in the methylation of other neurotransmitters, including serotonin to melatonin.
  • Lipid Metabolism:
    • Involved in the synthesis of phosphatidylcholine from phosphatidylethanolamine.

questions.text:
Tyrosine is involved in the synthesis of multiple neurotransmitters. Match the following neurotransmitters with the corresponding enzymes involved in their synthesis?

 


	
		
			
			Neurotransmitter
			
			
			Enzyme
			
		
		
			
			1. Dihydroxy phenylalanine (DOPA)
			
			
			a. Dopamine beta-hydroxylase
			
		
		
			
			2. Dopamine
			
			
			b. N-methyl transferase
			
		
		
			
			3. Norepinephrine
			
			
			c. Tyrosine hydroxylase
			
		
		
			
			4. Epinephrine
			
			
			d. DOPA Decarboxylase
questions.solution:
Reaction

Enzyme

Tyrosine to dihydroxy phenylalanine (DOPA)

Tyrosine hydroxylase

DOPA to Dopamine

DOPA Decarboxylase (uses PLP as a coenzyme)

Dopamine to Norepinephrine

Dopamine beta-hydroxylase (depends on

Vitamin C)

Norepinephrine to epinephrine

N-methyl transferase (S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) is the methyl donor)

 

Synthesis of Neurotransmitters from Tyrosine- Dopamine, Norepinephrine and Epinephrine

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician due to poor weight gain, vomiting, and yellowing of the skin and eyes. Genetic testing confirms a deficiency in fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase. The physician recommends a low-protein diet and the drug Nitisinone. Which of the following is not an indication of Nitisinone?
questions.solution:
Correct answer D)Tyrosinemia type II

Nitisinone is not indicated for Tyrosinemia type II, which is caused by a deficiency in Tyrosine aminotransferase.

  • Nitisinone acts by inhibiting the enzyme parahydroxy-phenylpyruvate dioxygenase, thereby inhibiting tyrosine metabolism upstream and prevents the accumulation of toxic metabolites of the tyrosine degradation pathway.
  • Nitisinone should be administered with a diet strictly low in phenylalanine and tyrosine.

 

The main indications of Nitisinone are:

Tyrosinemia type I (Option A)

Nitisinone inhibits the enzyme Parahydroxy phenylpyruvate dioxygenase, preventing the tyrosine metabolism upstream and reducing the accumulation of toxic maleylacetoacetate and fumarylacetoacetate.

Alkaptonuria(Option B)

Nitisinone is used in the treatment of Alkaptonuria by inhibiting the formation of Homogentisic acid.

Hawkinsinuria (Option C)

Nitisinone is used to treat Hawkinsinuria, which is caused by a mutation in 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase.

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant presents with jaundice, hepatomegaly, and failure to thrive. The parents also report that the infant has episodes of vomiting and lethargy. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of tyrosine and succinylacetone in the blood and urine, along with signs of coagulopathy and renal tubular dysfunction. What is the most likely underlying metabolic disorder?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described, including jaundice, hepatomegaly, failure to thrive, and elevated levels of tyrosine and succinylacetone, is characteristic of Tyrosinemia type I, which is caused by a deficiency in fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase.

 

Disorders of Tyrosine Metabolism:

 

Disorder

Deficient Enzyme

Key Clinical Features

Tyrosinemia type I

Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase
  • Jaundice, hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, HCC, liver cirrhosis
  • Often presents with Fanconi syndrome and renal failure
  • Elevated tyrosine and succinylacetone (pathognomonic)

Tyrosinemia type II

Tyrosine aminotransferase
  • Painful corneal erosions, palmoplantar hyperkeratosis
  • Also known as oculocutaneous tyrosinemia
  • Elevated tyrosine

Tyrosinemia type III

p-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase
  • Recurrent seizures, intermittent ataxia
  • Elevated tyrosine and 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate

Alkaptonuria (Black urine disease)

Homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase
  • Dark urine, ochronosis, arthritis
  • Black or brown pigmentation of sclera (Ochronosis) and ear cartilage
  • Elevated homogentisic acid

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the clinic by his parents due to darkening of urine upon standing and brownish discolouration of the sclera and ear cartilage. The parents also report that their child has been experiencing joint pain. Upon further investigation, the physician suspects a tyrosine metabolic disorder and orders urine tests. Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described, including darkening of urine upon standing, brownish discolouration of the sclera and ear cartilage, and joint pain, is characteristic of Alkaptonuria, which is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase.

Garrod's tetrad in alkaptonuria

1. Homogentisic Aciduria

Presence of homogentisic acid in the urine, which turns dark upon standing or when exposed to air.

2. Ochronosis

 Deposition of dark pigment in connective tissues, particularly in the ear cartilage, sclera, and other connective tissues, leading to bluish-black discolouration.

3. Arthropathy

Degenerative joint disease, especially affecting the spine and large joints, leading to chronic pain and stiffness.

4. Cardiac Involvement

Includes heart valve calcification and atherosclerosis due to the deposition of pigment in cardiac tissues.

Reaction

Enzyme

Associated Disorder

Tyrosine → p-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate

Tyrosine transaminase

Tyrosinemia type II

p-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate → Homogentisate

p-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase

Tyrosinemia type III

Homogentisate → Maleylacetoacetate

Homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase

Alkaptonuria

Maleylacetoacetate → Fumarylacetoacetate

Maleylacetoacetate isomerase

-

Fumarylacetoacetate → Fumarate + Acetoacetate

Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase

Tyrosinemia type I
  • Loss-of-function mutation of p-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase (pHPPD) causes tyrosinemia type III, while a gain-of-function mutation causes Hawkinsinuria
